channel.title: Build 475
channel.description:
[code]Build #475
game:client applet:mg bytebuffer:e bytearray:pb cache:pg cacherepository:ke cacheloader:qd canvas:t censor:he handle:sh signhandler:ma filebuffer:wh filedownloader:ob fileondisk:hh hashtable:ag image:sc imageobserver:ng imageproducer:q inflater:qg packet:oa interface failed to hook... node:ub manual failed to hook... interfacestring:nb item:qa keyboard:ca midimap:ea midistream:bc model:fe character failed to hook... render3d:cd mouse:ge mouselogger:je mousewheel:dd mousewheelcomponent:o packetsecure:rg isaac:le region:og render2d:ba render:od exception:fb socket:ga string:sg cacheunpacker:f world:ug[/code]
My hook for character seems to have broke this update. They must have made changes.

item.title: Build 475
item.dc:creator: @_cake _cake
item.description:
@_cake wrote:

[quote=“ZeroFreeze, post:14, topic:158230”][quote author=koolpop0 link=topic=215657.msg1887683#msg1887683 date=1195546937]
what are we sopuse to do with these =)
[/quote]
MITB doesn’t support spoon feeding; please leave.

they show where different variables/methods are in a class

something along those lines…

Not really, what you’re talking about is a dump.

Jagex re-obfuscates their client code in every client update. Some bots have to access certain fields in certain classes to retrieve information, though. That’s where an updater is needed. It basically uses patterns to ‘hook’ (find) these fields and classes. After it has hooked the stuff, it injects interfaces and field accessors.[/quote]
what you mean is they define different classes my having them implement the correct interface(s) and inject accessor methods into classes to retrieve data.

Read full topic

item.title: Build 475
item.dc:creator: @Zero_Freeze ZeroFreeze
item.description:
@Zero_Freeze wrote:

koolpop0:

what are we sopuse to do with these =)

MITB doesn’t support spoon feeding; please leave.

[quote=“shangtsung1, post:13, topic:158230”]they show where different variables/methods are in a class

something along those lines…[/quote]
Not really, what you’re talking about is a dump.

Jagex re-obfuscates their client code in every client update. Some bots have to access certain fields in certain classes to retrieve information, though. That’s where an updater is needed. It basically uses patterns to ‘hook’ (find) these fields and classes. After it has hooked the stuff, it injects interfaces and field accessors.

Read full topic

item.title: Build 475
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

[quote=“qauters, post:7, topic:158230”][code]
Hooking CameraCurves

  • getCameraCurveX() added to class client gets STATIC int ph.r
  • getCameraCurveY() added to class client gets STATIC int rf.ob
    [/code][/quote]

theres a mistake in those two, they are mixed up,
rf.ob changes when you move the camera left/right, and ph.r changes when you move it up/down

i think ill start posting my updater log, it has less fields that you lots, but at least they work

Read full topic

item.title: Build 475
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:9, topic:158230”]Please don’t laugh about me, but I have two questions

  1. What does an updater exactly do? lol
  2. In Ollie’s output it says this: getState -> vb What does vb mean?[/quote]1. It injects accessor methods for various fields in the client, thus making us able to retrieve those values from the client.
  3. vb is the name of that specific variable (or field).

Read full topic

item.title: Build 475
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

a work in progress:
started yesterday, cut slack please

loaded 25 transforms Downloading /runescape.jar RS Revision #476 Client -> client getState -> vb MutableString -> sd getBytes -> q getHash -> U isMutable -> Y getLength -> Q Node -> od getPrevious -> i getNext -> o getNodeID -> d NodeList -> sc getHead -> o NodeSub -> bh getNextSub -> E getPrevSub -> w Packet -> ff getCurrentOffset -> ub Modelled -> ed getHeight -> Y Model -> o Creature -> ud getMessage -> ub NPC -> ra getDefinition -> Dc NPCDefinition -> id getType -> jb getName -> mb getActions -> vb Player -> nf getModel -> Jc getPkIcon -> Hc getName -> Qc getTeam -> Vc getPrayerIcon -> Fc getLevel -> Zc FileWrapper -> dg getFile -> d getRandomAccessFile -> b Interface -> vd getValueIndexArray -> u getCache -> Fc Item -> de getID -> nb getStackCount -> xb DataLink -> ih getUID -> r getCacheFolder -> j getApplet -> e getSystemEventQueue -> b ByteBuffer -> cf getBuffer -> j RuntimeExceptionWrapper -> fa getMessage -> e getThrowable -> d Decompressor -> dc getInflater -> e Mouse -> qc MouseWheel -> bd MouseWheelComponent -> ug Keyboard -> nh Canvas -> qg getComponent -> h Applet -> p Completed 36 individual hooks in 63ms.

Read full topic

item.title: Build 475
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

[quote=“yakman, post:5, topic:158230”]watch out, character did not hook fine, it might all look good, but the mistake is there, in all of us. (i call that class entity, so bare with me)
it seems they totally removed entity.height, now all the calculations with it use animable.height.
also, that field has changed its type to short, (it used to be int)
and i was wondering why i got null pointers, trying to add a method which gets height, but it was in the wrong class

check your logs for Animable.modelHeight and Entity.height, cause they probably get the same field, but class name changed

like this is the one i have for that

getHeight() added to "ud" gets type int "ud.Y"
getModelHeight() added to "ed" gets type int "ed.Y"

i cant check for the interfaceXY cause i dont know enough about the client as I’d like to :([/quote]

i had noticed this too, but as animable is superclass of your “entity” or my “creature”, it doesnt need to be injected.
just need to change the datatype in your interface from int to short.

as for interaface and menu, i think they broke with some of your updaters small errors.

getMenuOptionsCount -> rg.j isMenuOpen -> vc.t getMenuY -> ra.Mc getMenuX -> ob.u getMenuOptions -> ub.hb getMenuActions -> b.c

im sorry but i currently dont have interfaceX and interfaceY hooked

Read full topic

item.title: Build 475
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

watch out, character did not hook fine, it might all look good, but the mistake is there, in all of us. (i call that class entity, so bare with me)
it seems they totally removed entity.height, now all the calculations with it use animable.height.
also, that field has changed its type to short, (it used to be int)
and i was wondering why i got null pointers, trying to add a method which gets height, but it was in the wrong class

check your logs for Animable.modelHeight and Entity.height, cause they probably get the same field, but class name changed

like this is the one i have for that

getHeight() added to "ud" gets type int "ud.Y"
getModelHeight() added to "ed" gets type int "ed.Y"

i cant check for the interfaceXY cause i dont know enough about the client as I’d like to

EDIT: i was wrong to suggest that you can simply use animable.height as a drop in replacement, i just found another change about that, but im sure you’ll all figure it out. And people saying “no big changes” are misleading, it will look like a big change when your bots start clicking in the wrong place.

Read full topic
